settings.title: #Root2Renew
settings.text: No Matter The Path, We Share The Same Root

settings.title: Plastic Lifecycle
settings.text: The majority of plastics in offshore environments date from the 1990s and earlier, as it takes roughly 500 years for a single piece of plastic to completely break down. Taking this into account, any plastic used in the 1990s won't break down completely until 2400 or even later!

settings.title: Hidden in Plain Sight
settings.text: In coastal regions, 79% of plastic found was less than 5 years old. Approximately 3% of global plastic waste enters the ocean each year (through rivers and multiple ports of entry), and while that may seem a small percentage, it equates to a staggering 99.6 metric tons within 30 miles of the coast.Over 82 metric tons of plastic and 40 metric tons of microplastic end up washing up, being buried or resurfacing on shorelines, only to re-enter the oceans.

settings.title: The Big Problem With Microplastics
settings.text: More than 5 trillion plastic particles are estimated to be in the world's surface waters.

settings.title: It's estimated by 2050 there will be more plastic than fish in our oceans

settings.text: With the production and use of plastics, we are overusing the natural resources and the ecosystems of our planet.
